subject: Investing
title: Maximum Drawdown Explained
description: Learn Maximum Drawdown Explained in one minute.

hook.text: From its 2007 peak, the S&P 500 fell 57%. That's the kind of number that shakes your faith.

buildup.text: Maximum drawdown is the largest peak-to-trough decline a portfolio has ever experienced.

discovery.text: A 50% drop requires a 100% gain just to break even. The math of losses is punishing.

twist.text: Every strategy's actual maximum drawdown is always worse than its backtestâ€”because the worst hasn't happened yet.

climax.text: Sizing your stock allocation so the worst drawdown won't force you to sell is the golden rule.

punchline.text: Plan for the drawdown you can survive, not the one you expect.

quiz.question: What gain is needed to recover from a 50% loss?
